sections.section: This tutorial demonstrates a simple message flow that connects to IBM's Internet of Things Foundation and receives events published by a device simulator over the MQTT protocol. The message flow writes the event data to a file.

MQTT is a open protocol for remote communication using a publish and subscribe model. Devices and applications can publish data on named topics and other applications or devices can subscribe to receive data that are published on particular topics. IBM Internet of Things (IoT) Foundation hosts a quickstart demonstration service. This tutorial connects to that service and illustrates how to use a message fow to receive data over MQTT. To publish the data, you will use the device simulator provided by the IoT Foundation.

IBM Internet of Things (IoT) Foundation hosts an MQTT broker on the internet and provides a quickstart demonstration service. This tutorial connects to that service and illustrates how to use a message fow to receive data over MQTT. To publish the data, you will use the device simulator provided by the IoT Foundation.

overview.name: Create
overview.heading: Create the message flow and the device
overview._createComment: A description of what will happen when the user clicks Import.

sections.section: Create a device that is connected to IoT Foundation and will publish data on a topic that the message flow can subscribe to.

details.details: On your smartphone/tablet/computer, start the simulator by browsing to http://quickstart.internetofthings.ibmcloud.com/iotsensor. The simulator connects automatically and starts publishing data. Keep your simulator window active and in the foreground.
Take a note of the MAC address of the device. This is seen in the top right of the device screen. You will need this to complete the configuration of the message flow.

sections.section: Import and complete the configuration of the message flow.

details.details: Click the Import button on the right of this view and the MQTTSubscribe application which includes a partially complete Message flow will be imported into your workspace.
The MQTTSubscribe message flow should be open in the Message Flow editor. If not, locate it under the flows section of the MQTTSubscribe application and double click to open it for editing.
Select the MQTTSubscribe node in the message flow and look at the Properties view

The Client ID property is blank and must be configured with a valid value. When connecting to the IoT Foundation quickstart, the Client ID must be of the form a:quickstart:<unique-name>. Chose a value for <unique-name> that is unlikely to be chosen by anyone else and enter the Client ID field. For example, chosing my name and birth year to avoid clashing with other people, I would enter a:quickstart:hosie75.

The Topic name property is blank and must be configured with a valid value. When connecting to the IoT Foundation quickstart to receive data, topic name must be of the form iot-2/type/+/id/<deviceid>/evt/+/fmt/+ where <deviceid> is the MAC address of the device whose data you are subscribing to - with colons removed and all letters in lower case. Refer to the MAC Address of the device that you simulated in the earlier step and enter the whole topic name. For example, if the MAC Address of your device is C2:AC:80:42:DA:D7 then the Topic name must be entered as iot-2/type/+/id/c2ac8042dad7/evt/+/fmt/+.
Ensure that there no errors associated with the message flow.

overview.name: Prepare
overview.heading: Deploy Application
overview._prepareComment: A description of what just happened when the user clicked Import, and what will happen when the user clicks Deploy.

sections.section: Before deploying the application, we must make sure that the file system is ready for the data to be written to the output file by the message flow.
The file output node is configured to write the data to a file in the output directory C:\fileout

details.details: Create the output directory C:\fileout on your local filesystem or change the Directory property of the FileOutput node to a directory that exists and your current user id has write access.
If you are using Linux, then you will probably need to change the Directory property.

sections.section: Once you have completed these steps, click Deploy and the MQTTSubscribe application will be deployed to your default Integration Server. The message flow will be connected to the IoT foundation ready to receive the data published by your device.

overview.name: Run
overview.heading: Follow these steps to complete the tutorial
overview._runComment: The full steps for the user to run through the tutorial. Use 'sections' to render paragraphs, 'steps' with a type of 'ordered' or 'unordered' to render HTML lists, and 'substeps' to render nested lists.

sections.section: The message flow will immediately start receving data, that is published by the device simulator that you launched in the Create step, and will write that data to a file in the directory that you created in the prepare step.
Change some of the metrics ( temparature/humidity) on the device simulator and open the output file again to see new events with those values appended at the end of the file.
In addition to this, you can use the flow exerciser to inspect other information, about the publication, that is avaialbe in the message flow

details.details: Open the MQTTSubscribe message flow, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to start recording the message path through the flow.
Wait a few seconds to ensure that, at least one, event is published.

In the Integration Toolkit Flow Exerciser toolbar, click the View Path icon to highlight the message path through the message flow. Click on any highlighted connection to see the message data that passed between the MQTTSubscribe node and the FileOutput node.
In the Message tree, you will see the Properties folder followed by a JSON folder that shows the same data that was written to the output file.

NOTE: the data is formated as XML by the UI for the puposes of rendering it through the flow exerciser but in reality, it remains as JSON as passes from IoT foundation, through the message flow and into the output file.

Expand the LocalEnvironment folder and you will see extra information about the publication. It woudl be possible to add other nodes to the message flow that could process this information or even copy it to the output file.
